column2: Turtling Up: Meeting the Turtle!
What you'll do
Riley has a new friend she'd like you to meet - The Turtle! He's the best friend to learn programming with!
Hey {{user_name}}! Everyone learns differently, so we're going to learn programming in a different way today. I want to introduce you to the Turtle!
I'll open up TurtleBlocks for you - but you can always find it on the Desktop.

OK! This program is how we're going to interact with the Turtle. The Turtle is little software "creature" that you can give orders to. Using the blocks in this program, you can tell the Turtle how to move.
The Turtle leaves a trail behind it, and you can use the trail to draw shapes and experiment with programming! Yeah, that's right - giving orders to the Turtle is a kind of programming!
TurtleBlocks has a lot of buttons, but don't worry. The top bar of buttons is mostly used for switching between different groups of instructions for the Turtle.
To use an instruction, you first click the button for the group you want, then drag the instruction you want into the blue area, and connect it to the other instructions to make it work.
Let's start with something simple. We'll just tell the turtle to move, turn, and move again.
Click the button with an image of a Turtle in the upper left to open the "Turtle" command group. From there, drag out 4 instructions: 2 forwards, and 2 lefts.
Once you have them out on the field, drag them into the 'jaws' of the Start block so that they're in the order forward, left, forward, left.
You can leave all the numbers as they are - now click the Snail button on the far right end of the top bar to get the Turtle moving!
Cool, huh? The turtle starts looking for instructions at the beginning of the 'jaws' of the Start block, and then marches down the list until it gets to the end.

In this case, you told the Turtle to go forward, then left, then forward, then left again. When you give the Turtle directions, it acts from its current point of view, which is why it ended up facing the bottom of the screen after the second left.
Let's try changing the details of those commands - the turtle doesn't always have to turn 90 degrees left, after all!
Double-click the purple boxes in the commands and change them to 200, 45, 50, 45 - The turtle will now move farther and turn less sharply.
Click the Snail button again and see how the turtle responds to your changes.

You can try changing the order of the instructions if you like - see how it changes the turtle's behavior! You can also click the eraser button on the top row of buttons, right next to the rabbit button, to clear the Turtle's drawing's away.

Let's use the Turtle to draw a triangle. We'll need a total of 3 forward instructions, but we'll only need 2 left instructions. With those limits, can you think of how to make the Turtle draw a triangle?
If you try it, you'll see that it's more complex than you think!
The way to solve this is to remember that the sum of inner angles of a triangle is 180 degrees... but what about the outer angles? Each one of those is equal to 180 degrees - the inner angle.

So, to draw a triangle, have your turns be 120 degrees. 180 - 120 = 60, and 60 * 3 = 180, the sum of all the angles in a triangle! Also, all your sides will need to be the same length - if a triangle's angles are all the same, the sides need to be the same too!
Great triangle! If you drew an equilateral triangle, try drawing a right triangle! You can also play around with the commands to draw other shapes.
Drawing a shape is fun - but it's kind of a pain to drag all those instructions around and change the values for all of them. What if there was a way to do it faster?
Click the "circling arrows" button at the top of the screen to open another command group, and drag the repeat block into the blue area.
Now, drag a forward block and a left block into the 'jaws' of the repeat block.

Remove all the other blocks from the 'jaws' of the Start block, and drag the repeat block in. You can just leave the other blocks hanging around - if they aren't connected to start, the Turtle can't see them!
Set your forward block's number to 75, and your left block's number to 45 by double-clicking the purple boxes on each block.
Double-click the purple box on the repeat node and set the number to 8.
Now, press the Snail button and away we go!
Cool, huh? That's an octagon!
But, you know, I can think of something even better than an octagon's 8 fantastic sides and 8 awesome angles...
We're going to use every tool we have in TurtleBlocks to create something really cool! ^_^

OK, first, let's get make sure our shape is filled in - Switch to the 'pencil' command group, and grab the 'start fill' and 'end fill' blocks. Put start fill before the repeat block, and put end fill after the repeat block.
Whenever you're trying to do a specific thing, it's always important to test your programs! Let's test our filled-in shape by clicking the snail button!
Nice. If you don't see what we're doing.... think about why we might have left the Turtle colored red!
This next set of instructions is pretty specific - I figured them out ahead of time and it took me a little while to get the right values, so check your work carefully!
We're gonna need a shopping list-worth of new nodes to make this work, so let's get going.
From the "Turtle" command group, we need a left block, a right block, and 2 forward blocks.
From the "Pencil" command group we need the pen up, pen down, and set color blocks.
From the "Colors" command group we need the white block.
From the "Notebook" command group we need the set scale, and show blocks.
Now that you've dragged all those nodes out, let's get them all into the correct order.
Below end fill, add pen up - This will stop the Turtle from drawing any lines while we do some precise movement!
After pen up, add left with a value of 90, forward with a value of 178, right with a value of 90, and then forward with a value of 28.
Next, it's Pen down, then set color, and drag our white block into the little slot on the right side of set color.
Then set scale with a value of 100, and finally, show with a value of STOP!

Now it's time to test everything! If you want to clean out the screen first, you can press the Eraser button, but otherwise, press the Snail button and watch our Turtle go! Watch as the instructions change color while the program runs. If anything goes wrong, you'll see where it happens!
If everything is right, you should have a stop sign... which, of course, is an octagon!

Try experimenting with all the instructions we used to do this - you should have a pretty good idea of what they do if you watched the Turtle step through them. As a challenge, try making a Stop sign that's twice as big as this one! Or maybe, if you're feeling confident, try making a Yield sign!
